question.text: Glycosidic bonds are considered which of the following types of bonds?

explanation.concept_text: Glycosidic bonds (shown below), also called glycosidic linkages, are considered covalent bonds formed via dehydration/condensation reactions occurring between two monosaccharides that join resulting in a loss of a water molecule for each covalent bond formed. Covalent bonds are a type of bond where electrons are shared either between atoms of identical electronegativities equally (non-polar covalent) or with differing electronegativities (polar covalent) unequally. CC By 4.0

question.text: Alpha helices and beta sheets are connected to their respective strands with which of the following bonds?

explanation.concept_text: Alpha helices (shown below) and beta sheets are connected to their respective strands with the use of hydrogen bonds (bonds occurring when hydrogen is bonded to either fluorine, oxygen, or nitrogen). Hydrogen bonding is the most prevalent interaction that occurs between carboxyl and amino groups of adjacent amino acids forming a polypeptide's most common secondary structures, the alpha helix and beta sheets. CC By 4.0

question.text: The bonds to create the tertiary structure of proteins can be associated with all of the following EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: The tertiary structure of a protein (shown below) represents the three-dimensional or overall shape of a protein caused by interactions of amino acid side chains, such as hydrophobic interactions, Vander der Waals interactions, ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, and disulfide bridges. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following connects the amino acids of the primary structure of proteins?

explanation.concept_text: The primary structure of a protein (shown below) is comprised of a linear sequence of amino acids . These amino acids are linked via a peptide or covalent bond that attaches one AA’s carboxyl group and the other AA’s amino group together by undergoing dehydration reactions. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following lists the correct order from smallest to largest?

explanation.concept_text: Protons are subatomic particles with a +1 electrical charge. Atoms , shown below, are known as the smallest unit of matter that still retains the properties of an element. They are comprised of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Finally, molecules form when two or more atoms join by chemical bonds. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following best describes a molecule?

options.label: A.
options.text: Made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons

options.label: B.
options.text: Group of two or more atoms

options.label: C.
options.text: Group of two or more neutrons

options.label: D.
options.text: Group of two or more protons

options.label: E.
options.text: Group of two or more electrons

correct_answer_text: Group of two or more atoms

explanation.concept_text: Molecules are formed when two or more atoms join together by the use of chemical bonds (covalent bonds), as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: The bond in red is which type of bond?

explanation.concept_text: Polar covalent bonds are chemical bonds formed between atoms that share electrons and have different electronegativities. On the other hand, hydrogen bonds are a type of bond formed when a Hydrogen (H) atom is bound to a highly electronegative atom (such as F, O, or N), causing the Hydrogen atom to take on a more positive charge. The more positively charged hydrogen atom is then attracted to another highly electronegative atom with at least one lone pair of electrons (typically F, O, or N). You may be wondering why the bond in red is not a hydrogen bond. The hydrogen bond shown in the picture is polar covalent because it is a direct covalent bond between N and H atoms. A hydrogen bond would only be formed in this case if this ammonia molecule interacted with another ammonia molecule, as seen below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following bonds occurs due to the even sharing of electrons between two atoms with similar electronegativity?

explanation.concept_text: Covalent non-polar bonds are involved with the even or equal sharing of electrons between two atoms of similar or the same electronegativity. Different types of covalent bonds are shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following bonds occur due to the uneven sharing of electrons between two atoms with different electronegativity?

explanation.concept_text: Covalent polar bonds occur when an atom is bonded to another more electronegative atom preventing equal sharing of electrons between atoms, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is considered a universal solvent?

explanation.concept_text: Solvents can be described as a substance’s dissolving agent, while the thing that gets dissolved is described as the solute . In the scenario of putting sugar in water, water acts as the solvent while sugar acts as the solute. The image below shows NaCl mixed with water. Note that hydrogen will encircle negatively charged ions, while oxygen will encircle positively charged ions. Water is a very reliable solvent primarily due to the polarity it contains. However, it is important to note that, although the versatility of water as a solvent is vast, water is not a universal solvent. If it was, any container holding water, including our cells would be dissolved. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following properties of water make it an effective biological solvent?

explanation.concept_text: Water’s polarity caused by the dipoles of H 2 O allows it to function as a great solvent for polar substances and ions. This is due to polar molecules being more attracted to water i.e., being hydrophilic . Whereas non-polar molecules are repelled by water i.e., they are hydrophobic . This results in water making non-polar molecules aggregate together to avoid other water molecules, while polar substances dissolve further in the polar water. Shown below is an image of a water molecule: CC By 4.0

question.text: The high heat of vaporization of water is explained by its __________.

explanation.concept_text: The heat of vaporization of a substance can be described as the quantity of heat that a liquid must absorb to transition from a liquid to a gaseous state. Because water can form hydrogen bonds with itself, it has a high heat capacity (the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a certain substance). The high heat capacity means that water requires more heat to increase its temperature, so it will also require more heat to vaporize the water.

question.text: If a large body of water is surrounded by a very high atmospheric temperature, which of the following will occur?

options.label: A.
options.text: The temperature will be relatively stable

options.label: D.
options.text: The surface tension of the water will decrease drastically

options.label: E.
options.text: The surface tension of the water will increase drastically

correct_answer_text: The temperature will be relatively stable

explanation.concept_text: One of water’s unique properties is it relatively high specific heat capacity when compared to other materials. The specific heat capacity of a substance is defined as the amount of heat that must be absorbed or lost for 1g of that substance to change its temperature by 1 degree Celsius. Water’s high heat capacity allows it to minimize temperature changes in organisms living in large bodies of water and the environment.

question.text: Why is ice able to float in liquid water?

options.label: B.
options.text: Ice is less dense than water

options.label: C.
options.text: Water is less dense than ice

options.label: E.
options.text: H-bonds become more fluid in ice compared to H-bonds in water

correct_answer_text: Ice is less dense than water

explanation.concept_text: Unlike most substances you will encounter, water is one of the select few that are less dense as a solid than it is as a liquid due to the lattice structure of ice (shown below in (a)). This means that while other substances may contract and become denser as they solidify, water instead expands due to the presence of extensive hydrogen bonding . This allows ice to float (shown below in (b)), as its density in the solid phase is less than water’s density when present in the liquid phase. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following occurs on a molecular level as water freezes?

explanation.concept_text: At low enough temperatures, water molecules begin to get locked into a crystal-like lattice structure (shown below in (a)) of hydrogen bonds, resulting in the formation of ice. As the H-bonds become more structured, ice becomes less dense than liquid as water molecules get spaced further apart causing ice to float (shown below in (b)). CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following properties of water allows insects to “walk” on its surface?

explanation.concept_text: Water's polarity and ability to hydrogen bond makes it cohesive (attracted to like substances). Water's cohesive forces with other water molecules are stronger than the interaction of water with the air around it, creating water's high surface tension . Water's high surface tension along with its adhesive nature (ability to be attracted to unlike substances) allows insects to walk on water, as shown below. CC By 4.0

question.text: In the wintertime, a pond forms an ice surface. Which of the following best explains why?

options.label: A.
options.text: Water is less dense than ice

options.label: B.
options.text: The crystalline structure of ice is less dense than water

options.label: C.
options.text: Cohesive properties of water allow ice to float

options.label: D.
options.text: Adhesive properties of water allow ice to float

options.label: E.
options.text: The high heat of vaporization prevents ice from ever melting

correct_answer_text: The crystalline structure of ice is less dense than water

explanation.concept_text: During the wintertime, water molecules begin to get locked into a crystal-like lattice structure (shown below in (a)) of hydrogen bonds , resulting in the formation of ice. As the H-bonds become more structured, ice becomes less dense than liquid as water molecules get spaced further apart causing ice to float (shown below in (b)). The ability for a pond to form an ice surface as a result of it having a lower density as a solid than as a liquid is a key factor in the suitability of the environments required for life. Furthermore, over time, if ice began to sink, all the ponds, lakes and even the oceans would freeze, making life as we know it on Earth impossible. CC By 4.0

question.text: In plants, the combination of the attraction between water molecules and to the inner surface of vessels allows for the movement of water against gravity, up the roots of a plant, to the leaves. Which of the following terms best explains this phenomenon?

explanation.concept_text: In this question, capillary action (as shown in the images below) can be defined as the ascension of water from the plant roots to leaves against the force of gravity due to the adhesive forces between water molecules and the plant cell walls and the cohesive forces between water molecules. CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0

question.text: In plants, which of the following best describes the attraction between water molecules and the xylem, allowing for the movement of water against gravity?

explanation.concept_text: Adhesion is known as the clinging of one substance to another (different) substance. Adhesion of water molecules to the xylem by the formation of hydrogen bonds helps counter the downward pull of gravity, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: The capillary action of water is related to both __________.

explanation.concept_text: As a result of water’s polar covalent bonds, water has the ability to form hydrogen bonds with itself and other neighboring polar molecules. Capillary action occurs as a result of both water’s cohesive nature i.e., the force that holds water molecules together, along with its adhesive nature i.e., the ability to “stick” to other polar molecules, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is a monosaccharide?

explanation.concept_text: Monosaccharides are classified as single sugar molecules, known as simple sugars. Examples of monosaccharides include fructose and glucose, as shown below. Monomers such as these are the building blocks of more complex carbohydrates. Canadian DAT Pro-Tip: “Monosaccharide” - Mono = single, sacchar = sugar) CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following are used to link carbohydrates to each other?

explanation.concept_text: Glycosidic linkages are covalent bonds formed between two monosaccharides as a result of a dehydration reaction. An example of this is when one molecule of glucose and one molecule of fructose are linked together through glycosidic bonds to form a sucrose disaccharide, as shown below. CC By 4.0

question.text: A key trait of all organic molecules is the presence of ________.

explanation.concept_text: Living matter is composed mostly of carbon , hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, along with some amounts of sulfur and phosphorus. Furthermore, the vast amount of biological diversity stems from carbon’s ability to form a wide number of molecules with varying number of bonds.

question.text: Which of the following is a disaccharide?

explanation.concept_text: A disaccharide is a sugar that consists of two monosaccharides that have joined via a glycosidic linkage (covalent bond) after undergoing a dehydration/condensation reaction . For example, the common disaccharide sucrose also known as table sugar, forms when monomers glucose and fructose undergo a dehydration reaction, joining together to form sucrose, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following occurs to create a polymer from monomers?

explanation.concept_text: The majority of macromolecules are formed via individual building blocks known as monomers . Monomers then combine together with the use of covalent bonds, ultimately, forming an even larger molecule known as a polymer . When this reaction occurs, water is released as a byproduct. Dehydration/condensation reactions can be described as the method to put together single subunits while losing water in order to form larger molecules. A dehydration synthesis reaction is shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is required to break down a polymer into monomers?

explanation.concept_text: Polymers break down into individual monomers during a process known as hydrolysis . This is essentially the process of inserting a water molecule across a covalent bond in order to break it into two components, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following defines a single sugar molecule?

explanation.concept_text: It is important to remember that carbohydrates include both simple sugars (monosaccharides) , and the polymers of simple sugars (polysaccharides) . Monosaccharides are the smallest monomer units of carbohydrates. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following defines lactose?

explanation.concept_text: A disaccharide is a sugar that consists of two monosaccharides that have joined via a glycosidic linkage (covalent bond) after undergoing a dehydration/condensation reaction . For example, the disaccharide lactose, also found naturally in milk, forms when monomer glucose is linked to galactose via undergoing a dehydration reaction, joining together to form lactose (shown below). CC By 4.0

question.text: All of the following are carbohydrates EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Monosaccharides, disaccharides, and polysaccharides all fall under the category of carbohydrates . Starch, glycogen, cellulose, and chitin are all common examples of polysaccharides. Carotenoids, however, are lipid molecules that function as pigments.

question.text: If a series of many monosaccharides are bound together via dehydration synthesis, which of the following best defines this new molecule?

explanation.concept_text: Polysaccharides are described as a long chain of monosaccharides or single sugar units joined by glycosidic bonds after undergoing dehydration/condensation reactions in which water molecules are also released. For example, starch, glycogen, cellulose (shown below), and chitin are common examples of polysaccharides. CC By 4.0

question.text: Maltose is broken down into glucose molecules as water is added to the chemical bond. This breakdown mechanism is also known as _______________.

explanation.concept_text: Disaccharides such as maltose, along with other polymers break down into individual monomers during a process known as hydrolysis . This is essentially the process of inserting a water molecule across a covalent bond to break it into two components (in this case being two molecules of glucose), as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Sucrose is made up of which two monosaccharides?

explanation.concept_text: The common disaccharide sucrose , also known as table sugar, forms when monomers glucose and fructose undergo a dehydration reaction , joining together to form sucrose (shown below). CC By 4.0

question.text: Lactose is made up of which two monosaccharides?

explanation.concept_text: The disaccharide lactose , also found naturally in milk, forms when monomer glucose is linked to stereoisomer galactose via undergoing a dehydration reaction, joining together to form lactose (shown below). CC By 4.0

question.text: Maltose is made up of which two monosaccharides?

explanation.concept_text: The disaccharide maltose (shown below) is formed when two molecules of glucose are linked together through glycosidic bonds by undergoing dehydration/condensation reactions . CC By 4.0

question.text: Which carbohydrate is used by plants to store energy?

explanation.concept_text: Storage polysaccharides are utilized by both plants and animals to store sugars for later use. However, plants do this by storing starch in the form of amylose and amylopectin (shown below), which is described as a polymer of glucose. CC By 4.0

question.text: An unknown cell is treated with iodine to test for the presence of starch. The test result is positive. The cell is, most likely, a ______________.

explanation.concept_text: Storage polysaccharides are utilized by both plants and animals to store sugars for later use. However, plants do this by storing starch which is described as a polymer of glucose. A common procedure used to test a cell for the presence of starch is known as the Iodine Test (shown below). A positive test result will indicate the presence of starch by forming a distinct blue-black colored complex. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which carbohydrate is used by animals to store energy?

explanation.concept_text: Storage polysaccharides are utilized by both plants and animals to store sugars for later use. However, animals do this by storing glycogen . Glycogen (shown below) is a polymer of glucose, it is similar in structure to amylopectin (branched form of plant starch), however, much more branching is present in glycogen. CC By 4.0

question.text: Both starch and glycogen are __________.

explanation.concept_text: Both starch and glycogen are alpha glucose molecules that are known as storage polysaccharides. Starch is the storage polysaccharide found in plants. It is composed of glucose monomers that are joined by either alpha 1- 4 or alpha 1- 6 glycosidic bonds. Note, that “1 – 4” and “1 – 6” refer to the specific number of the carbon. On the other hand, animals store the alpha glucose molecule glycogen, which can be described as the more highly branched equivalent of amylopectin (branched form of starch) in plants.

question.text: The structural integrity of plants is supported by which of the following polysaccharides?

explanation.concept_text: The structural integrity of plants is supported by the polysaccharide cellulose (shown below). Cellulose is composed of glucose monomers that are linked via beta 1-4 glycosidic bonds . They are held together in a parallel orientation, providing strong building blocks that plants can use to build tough cell walls (note, that cellulose is never branched). CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is stored in the human liver and used as an energy source?

explanation.concept_text: Animals, including humans, use the storage polysaccharide glycogen (shown below) as an energy source. Vertebrates such as humans do this by storing glycogen, an alpha glucose molecule with extensive branching mainly in the liver and muscle cells. When demand for sugar increases, glycogen in the body undergoes hydrolysis to release glucose to cells. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is produced in plants, but cannot be digested by the human body?

explanation.concept_text: The structural integrity of plants is supported by the polysaccharide cellulose (shown below). Cellulose is composed of glucose monomers that are linked via beta 1-4 glycosidic bonds. They are held together in a parallel orientation, providing strong building blocks that plants can use to build tough cell walls. Enzymes in the human body do not have the ability to hydrolyze the beta linkages of cellulose. Thus, when cellulose enters our digestive tract, it simply passes through and gets eliminated. CC By 4.0

question.text: Starch in plant cells is analogous to which of the following in animal cells?

explanation.concept_text: Both starch and glycogen function as energy storage polysaccharides . Starch is the energy storage polysaccharide found in plants, while glycogen is the energy storage polysaccharide found in animals. Both are composed of alpha glucose monomers .

question.text: Chitin in insect exoskeletons is analogous to which of the following in plant cells?

explanation.concept_text: Chitin (shown below) is a structural polysaccharide used by insects to build their exoskeletons and by many fungi to build their cell walls. This is analogous to plants using the structural polysaccharide cellulose as their cell walls building material. Like cellulose, chitin also has beta linkages , however, the glucose monomer of chitin instead has a nitrogen-containing appendage. CC By 4.0

question.text: Chitin is used in both insect exoskeletons and in which of the following?

explanation.concept_text: Chitin (shown below) is a structural polysaccharide, containing beta linkages used by insects to build their exoskeletons and by many fungi to build their cell walls. Chitin is similar in structure to cellulose; however, the glucose monomer of chitin instead has a nitrogen-containing appendage. CC By 4.0

question.text: Both cellulose and chitin are __________.

explanation.concept_text: Both the structural polysaccharides, cellulose and chitin are classified as beta glucose molecules . However, it is important to note they are not identical, the glucose monomer of chitin instead has a nitrogen-containing appendage.

question.text: Lipids can be associated with all the following EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Of the classes of biological molecules, lipids (shown below) are considered the only ones that are not known as true polymers. However, they are grouped together due to all lipids sharing a common trait; they are hydrophobic and mix very poorly with water because they contain many non-polar covalent bonds. CC By 4.0

question.text: If a lipid is made up of three fatty acids and a glycerol backbone, which of the following must the molecule be?

explanation.concept_text: Although phospholipids, steroids, waxes, and cholesterol are all important classes of lipids , they are formed through other means. The lipid class that contains the triglycerides (another name for fat) is formed when three fatty acid molecules are joined to a glycerol backbone by the use of an ester linkage, as shown below. CC By 4.0

question.text: The structure of saturated triglycerides can be associated with all the following EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: The terms “saturated” vs. “unsaturated” regarding triglycerides are commonly seen. These terms are specifically referring to the fatty acid’s hydrocarbon chain. If there is an absence of double bonds, then as many hydrogen atoms can bind to the hydrocarbon chain as possible. This would describe a saturated fatty acid. The absence of double bonds prevents kinks from forming as commonly seen in unsaturated fatty acids, thus, saturated fatty acids can pack in straight, tight chains, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Unsaturated triglycerides contain which of the following?

explanation.concept_text: When a triglyceride contains double bonds within its structure, it is known as an “unsaturated triglyceride” . The presence of a double bond allows for the indication of cis/trans configuration. If the hydrogen atoms are on opposite planes across the double bond, it is described as being in a trans configuration. On the other hand, if the hydrogens are on the same plane, it will be considered a cis unsaturated triglyceride. The “cis” double bond present, creates a “kink” , preventing the fatty acids from having straight chains, or stacking densely, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Phospholipids are most similar in structure to __________.

explanation.concept_text: Phospholipids (shown below)are considered one of the major plasma membrane components of a cell that comprises its outermost layers. Similar to fats, they contain fatty acid chains attached to a glycerol backbone. However, phospholipids are bound to two fatty acids and a glycerol backbone compared to being attached to three fatty acids and a glycerol backbone as seen in triacylglycerols. CC By 4.0

question.text: If a lipid is made up of two fatty acids and a phosphate group bound to a glycerol backbone, which of the following must the molecule be?

explanation.concept_text: Phospholipids (shown below) can be described as molecules that contain two fatty acids and a phosphate group bound to a glycerol backbone. Phospholipids differ when compared to triglycerides . Fats such as triglycerides are composed of three fatty acid tails attached to a glycerol backbone. CC By 4.0

question.text: Phospholipids can self-assemble at the plasma membrane because of their __________.

explanation.concept_text: Phospholipids (shown below), which consist of two fatty acids and a phosphate group being bound to a glycerol backbone are known as amphipathic molecules. Amphipathic describes a molecule with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties. The phosphate head of a phospholipid is polar, hydrophilic, and negatively charged. While the fatty acid chains are non-polar, hydrophobic, and uncharged. This is what describes phospholipid’s ability to self-assemble, as hydrophobic regions namely the fatty acid chains will aggregate together avoiding water, while phosphate groups face outward due to being hydrophilic. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following describes the structure of a steroid?

options.label: A.
options.text: Three fatty acids and a glycerol backbone

options.label: B.
options.text: A three-carbon molecule with a hydroxyl group on each carbon

options.label: C.
options.text: Three six-membered rings and one five-membered ring

options.label: D.
options.text: Four pyrrole rings with a metal ion in the center

options.label: E.
options.text: Two fatty acids and a phosphate group

correct_answer_text: Three six-membered rings and one five-membered ring

explanation.concept_text: Steroids such as sex hormones, cholesterol, and corticosteroids, are characterized as lipids consisting of a carbon skeleton comprised of four fused rings – three six-membered rings and one five-membered ring, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is similar to carbohydrates in that they can store energy?

explanation.concept_text: Like carbohydrates, lipids also perform various functions within a cell. One, that is similar to carbohydrates, lipids function in, is storing energy within a cell. They do this by storing fat, as a means of long-term energy.

question.text: Cholesterol is considered to be which of the following?

explanation.concept_text: Cholesterol (shown below) is the most common class of steroids , and it is primarily synthesized in the liver. Like other steroids, it contains a four fused carbon ring structure and acts as a precursor to various important steroid molecules such as estrogen, testosterone, and progesterone. Furthermore, it also acts as the precursor to Vitamin D and bile salts. CC By 4.0

question.text: A scientist is studying lipids under a microscope. He notices the lipid he is looking at contains four fused rings. This is most likely a __________.

explanation.concept_text: Steroids do not resemble other lipids such as waxes, carotenoids, triglycerides, and phospholipids. They are grouped together and classified as lipids due to their hydrophobic nature and poor ability to mix with water. All steroids consist of four fused carbon ring structures, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which components make up the amphipathic property of phospholipids?

options.label: A.
options.text: The polar glycerol backbone and hydrophobic chains

options.label: B.
options.text: The polar phosphate head and a nonpolar hydrocarbon tail

options.label: C.
options.text: The polar OH groups in the glycerol backbone and a nonpolar chain

options.label: D.
options.text: The molecular geometry of phospholipids contributes to their amphipathic property

options.label: E.
options.text: The nonpolar chains interact with polar OH groups

correct_answer_text: The polar phosphate head and a nonpolar hydrocarbon tail

explanation.concept_text: Phospholipids (shown below) , which consist of two fatty acids and a phosphate group being bound to a glycerol backbone are known as being amphiphilic molecules. This means both hydrophobic and hydrophilic portions of the molecule are present. The phosphate head of a phospholipid is polar, hydrophilic, and negatively charged. The fatty acid chains are non-polar, hydrophobic, and uncharged. CC By 4.0

question.text: Lipid function can be associated with all the following EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Major role in the endocrine function of both male and female reproductive organs

options.label: B.
options.text: Acts as a secondary form of energy storage

options.label: C.
options.text: Aids in human body temperature regulation

options.label: D.
options.text: Maintains the structural integrity and membrane fluidity of cell membranes

explanation.concept_text: Lipids can be associated with all of the above option choices except Option E. Destruction of extraembryonic cells is a highly regulated process in development that is not associated with lipid function. Recall that lipids have a variety of function including energy storage and temperature regulation, but none of its functions relate to destruction or breakdown of cells.

question.text: Which of the following are used to create the structure of hemoglobin?

explanation.concept_text: Porphyrins are a type of organic molecule comprised of four joined pyrrole rings that are often complexed with a metal ion. Porphyrins are not a type of lipid. In the case of hemoglobin , the "heme" component is responsible for binding to oxygen, as shown below. It consists of a metal ion in the form of iron and a porphyrin ring that binds to the "globin" molecules. CC By 4.0

question.text: To prevent cell membrane rigidity, which of the following will occur?

options.label: A.
options.text: The cell will form an endospore

options.label: B.
options.text: The cell wall secretes ethylene into the membrane

options.label: C.
options.text: Cholesterol is incorporated into the membrane

options.label: D.
options.text: Saturated fatty acids are incorporated into the membrane

options.label: E.
options.text: Adipocytes are incorporated into the membrane

correct_answer_text: Cholesterol is incorporated into the membrane

explanation.concept_text: To prevent cell membrane rigidity , one approach would be to incorporate cholesterol into the membrane. This will allow the membrane to become more fluid and prevent excess rigidity.

question.text: Which of the following is added to the membrane at cold temperature?

explanation.concept_text: At low temperatures, cell membranes begin to increase in rigidity. In order to avoid this, cholesterol and unsaturated fatty acids are incorporated within the membrane. Unsaturated fatty acids have kinked chains and cannot pack together tightly. Cholesterol will also disrupt fatty acid packing. Together, this will allow for the prevention of an overly rigid membrane from forming, increasing fluidity .

question.text: In warm weather, which of the following should be added to the cell membrane to prevent excess fluidity?

explanation.concept_text: At higher temperatures, the cell membrane becomes more fluid and flexible. In order to avoid the cell membrane from collapsing, saturated fatty acids and cholesterol are added to restrict movement. Saturated fatty acids accomplish this because their fatty acid tails are fully saturated with hydrogen atoms, this allows them to become straight, pack tightly, and thus decrease fluidity.

question.text: Which of the following is the monomer of proteins?

explanation.concept_text: The monomers of proteins are known as amino acids . Amino acids are linked to one another via dehydration reactions to form peptide bonds . Each amino acid contains an amino group, carboxyl group, carbon, and an R group, as shown below. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following are the structural components of amino acids?

options.label: B.
options.text: DNA, fatty acid, and glycerol backbone

options.label: C.
options.text: Amino group, DNA, carbon, and R group

options.label: D.
options.text: Amino group, carboxyl group, carbon, and R group

options.label: E.
options.text: Amino group, carboxyl group, RNA, and R group

correct_answer_text: Amino group, carboxyl group, carbon, and R group

explanation.concept_text: An amino acid's structural components include a central asymmetric carbon to which a hydrogen atom, carboxyl group, amino group, and an R group are attached to, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: The component of amino acids that make them distinctive from each other is the ______________.

explanation.concept_text: The R group (shown below) of an amino acid specifies which class of amino acids it belongs to. The unique characteristics/variability of these groups causes an amino acid to form various types of bonds and interactions including but not limited to: ionic, hydrogen, disulfide, and nonpolar and polar interactions. CC By 4.0

question.text: Hemoglobin is classified as which of the following proteins?

explanation.concept_text: Transport proteins function in moving materials within an organism. Examples of transport proteins include hemoglobin (shown below) transporting/carrying oxygen and cytochromes transporting/carrying electrons. CC By 4.0

question.text: Proteins that function to catalyze chemical reactions are called which of the following?

explanation.concept_text: Enzymes are unique molecules that catalyze biochemical reactions by lowering the activation energy in both the forward and reverse directions. Most enzymes are proteins, but some can be made of RNA. CC By 4.0

question.text: Molecules that aid enzymes in their function and can serve as vitamins are ______.

explanation.concept_text: Cofactors can be described as non-protein molecules that assist enzymes. They include two classes: 1. If the cofactor is organic → Coenzyme (ex. Vitamins), as shown below. 2. If the cofactor is inorganic → Metal ions (ex. Fe 2+ , Mg 2+ ). CC By 4.0

question.text: Which protein structure is defined as the linear sequence of amino acids?

explanation.concept_text: The primary structure of a protein (shown below) is comprised of a linear sequence of amino acids. These amino acids are linked via a peptide or covalent bond that attaches one AA’s carboxyl group and the other AA’s amino group together by undergoing dehydration reactions. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following best describes the development of the secondary protein structure?

options.label: A.
options.text: Amino acids bound with peptide bonds

options.label: D.
options.text: Hydrogen bonding between amino and carboxyl groups of amino acids

correct_answer_text: Hydrogen bonding between amino and carboxyl groups of amino acids

explanation.concept_text: The secondary structure of a protein (shown below in the first image) results from intermolecular interactions between atoms of a polypeptide backbone (not the R-group). These interactions include things such as hydrogen bonding (bonds occurring when hydrogen is bonded to either fluorine, oxygen, or nitrogen) as the most prevalent interaction that occurs between carboxyl and amino groups of adjacent amino acids forming a polypeptide most common secondary structures, the alpha helix, and beta sheets (shown below in the second image). CC By 4.0 CC By 4.0

question.text: Alpha helices and beta sheets are present in which level of protein structure?

explanation.concept_text: The secondary structure of a protein results from intermolecular interactions between atoms of a polypeptide backbone (not the R group). These interactions include things such as hydrogen bonding (bonds occurring when hydrogen is bonded to either fluorine, oxygen, or nitrogen) as the most prevalent interaction that occurs between carboxyl and amino groups of adjacent amino acids forming a polypeptide most common secondary structures, the alpha helix and beta sheets , as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Tertiary protein structures form due to the __________.

options.label: A.
options.text: Interactions between the R groups of amino acids

options.label: C.
options.text: Amino acids joining via peptide bonds

options.label: D.
options.text: Beta sheets and alpha helices interactions

options.label: E.
options.text: Hydrogen bonding between amino and carboxyl groups of amino acids

correct_answer_text: Interactions between the R groups of amino acids

explanation.concept_text: The tertiary structure of a protein (shown below) represents the three-dimensional or overall shape of a protein caused by the largely non-covalent interactions of amino acid side chains , such as hydrophobic interactions, Van der Waals interactions, ionic bonds, and hydrogen bonds. Disulfide bridges are a covalent interaction that also contributes to the tertiary structure of a protein. CC By 4.0

question.text: Tertiary structures of proteins can contain all of the following interaction types EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: The tertiary structure of a protein (shown below) represents the three-dimensional or overall shape of a protein caused by the non-covalent interactions of amino acid side chains, such as hydrophobic interactions, Vander der Waals interactions, ionic bonds, hydrogen bonds, and disulfide bridges (an exception to non-covalent). CC By 4.0

question.text: Disulfide bonds are strong covalent bonds between which of the following?

explanation.concept_text: Disulfide bonds are strong covalent bonds formed by interactions between the amino acid cysteine side chains, ultimately forming disulfide linkages (S – S bonds). These disulfide linkages are the only covalent bond formed during the process of protein folding. CC By 4.0

question.text: A protein is considered to be in a quaternary structure if which of the following occurs?

explanation.concept_text: Some proteins are formed when separate peptide chain subunits interact and come together creating the quaternary structure of a protein, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following DNA base pairs requires the most energy to break?

explanation.concept_text: The four bases in DNA are adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T). These bases form specific pairs (A with T, and G with C), as shown below. The guanine and cytosine base pairing forms 3 hydrogen bonds and adenine and thymine form only 2 hydrogen bonds. Thus, the G-C base pair has the strongest interactions and requires the most amount of energy to break. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is true regarding protein denaturation?

options.label: A.
options.text: Protein denaturation leads to loss of tertiary structure only

options.label: B.
options.text: Protein denaturation leads to a loss of function

options.label: C.
options.text: Protein denaturation is the breakdown of a protein into individual amino acids

options.label: D.
options.text: Proteins with peptide bonds are more resistant to denaturation

correct_answer_text: Protein denaturation leads to a loss of function

explanation.concept_text: When proteins are taken out of their ideal pH ranges, temperatures, or solvents, denaturation may occur. Protein denaturation can be described as a protein being reversed back to its primary structure. Furthermore, protein denaturation also implies that all of the information needed for a protein to assume its native state (its folded, functional form) is encoded in its primary structure. Since a protein's function is dependent on its 3-dimensional structure, a denatured protein is non-functional.

question.text: The greatest determinant of a protein's function is __________.

explanation.concept_text: The greatest determinant of a protein’s function is described as a protein's structure (shown below). This is because its structure is dependent on its amino acid sequence and interactions present in both the amino acid side chains and the polypeptide backbone. Thus, if a protein begins to lose part of its structure, it may not be able to function as properly as it once did, if at all. CC By 4.0

question.text: All of the following are nitrogenous bases associated with DNA EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Adenine and guanine are known as purines (shown below) and are nitrogenous bases that are associated with both DNA and RNA. Thymine, cytosine and uracil are all classified as pyrimidines (shown below), however, only cytosine is seen in both DNA and RNA. Thymine is associated with DNA; however, uracil is only associated with RNA. CC By 4.0

question.text: Adenine and thymine pair with how many hydrogen bonds?

explanation.concept_text: Adenine and thymine (shown below) are known as nitrogenous bases . As a result of base pairing rules, adenine can only pair with thymine through the formation of two hydrogen bonds, while cytosine can only base pair with guanine through the formation of three hydrogen bonds. CC By 4.0

question.text: Cytosine and guanine pair with how many hydrogen bonds?

explanation.concept_text: Cytosine and guanine (shown below) are known as nitrogen bases. As a result of base pairing rules, cytosine can only base pair with guanine through the formation of three hydrogen bonds, while adenine can only pair with thymine through the formation of two hydrogen bonds. The additional guanine-cytosine hydrogen bond makes DNA that has a higher proportion of guanine and cytosoine  more difficult to break apart, requiring a higher temperature to denature the DNA. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is replaced by uracil in the nitrogenous bases of RNA?

explanation.concept_text: Adenine and guanine are known as purines (shown below) and are nitrogenous bases that are associated with both DNA and RNA. Thymine, cytosine, and uracil are all classified as pyrimidines (shown below), however, only cytosine is seen in both DNA and RNA. Thymine on the other hand is associated with DNA, however, is replaced by uracil in RNA, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following are purines?

explanation.concept_text: Nitrogenous bases can be classified as either purines or pyrimidines . The purines include both adenine (A) and guanine (G), as shown in the image below. Mnemonic: PURe As Gold CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following are pyrimidines?

explanation.concept_text: Nitrogenous bases can be classified as either purines or pyrimidines. The pyrimidines include cytosine (C), thymine (T, found only in DNA), and uracil (U, found only in RNA). Mnemonic: CUT the Pye CC By 4.0

question.text: Purines and pyrimidines have how many rings respectively?

explanation.concept_text: Nitrogenous bases can be classified as either purines or pyrimidines . The purines contain two rings, while the pyrimidines contain one ring. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following is a difference between DNA and RNA?

options.label: A.
options.text: DNA uses the nitrogenous base of uracil

options.label: B.
options.text: RNA uses the nitrogenous base of thymine

explanation.concept_text: DNA and RNA are both known as nucleic acids/polymers of nucleotides, with nitrogenous bases that can vary based on whether it is DNA or RNA, as shown below. One difference between the two is that RNA is usually single-stranded. CC By 4.0

question.text: DNA and RNA contain which sugars respectively?

explanation.concept_text: There are two types of pentose sugars found in nucleotides, these include deoxyribose (in DNA), and ribose (in RNA).  Both are similar in structure, however, ribose has an OH at the 2` position, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: DNA and RNA are both __________.

explanation.concept_text: Nucleic acids , the overall term for DNA and RNA (shown below), are essential to all forms of life and function to encode, express, and store genetic information. CC By 4.0

question.text: Nucleotides are made up of a __________.

options.label: A.
options.text: Nitrogenous base, a five-carbon sugar, and a phosphate group

options.label: B.
options.text: Nitrogenous base, a four-carbon sugar, and a phosphate group

options.label: C.
options.text: Nitrogenous base, a carboxyl group, and an amino acid

options.label: D.
options.text: Nitrogenous base, an amine group, and an amino acid

options.label: E.
options.text: Nitrogenous base, a carboxyl group, and an R group

correct_answer_text: Nitrogenous base, a five-carbon sugar, and a phosphate group

explanation.concept_text: Nucleotides are described as the monomers that make up nucleic acids and consists of a nitrogenous base, a five-carbon sugar, and a phosphate group, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: To form a nucleotide from a nucleoside, which of the following must be added?

explanation.concept_text: Nucleotides are described as the monomers that make up nucleic acids and consist of a nitrogenous base, a five-carbon sugar, and a phosphate group. However, nucleotides should not be confused with nucleosides (shown below), which consist of a sugar and a nitrogenous base. Thus, to form a nucleotide from a nucleoside, you must add a phosphate group . CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following does Guanine pair with?

explanation.concept_text: Cytosine and guanine are known as nitrogenous bases , as shown below. As a result of base pairing rules, guanine can only base pair with cytosine through the formation of three hydrogen bonds. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following does Uracil pair with?

explanation.concept_text: As a result of base pairing rules, adenine can only pair with thymine through the formation of two hydrogen bonds in DNA, as shown below. Adenine is also associated with RNA; However, thymine is replaced with the pyrimidine uracil , which instead binds to adenine. CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following does Thymine pair with?

explanation.concept_text: As a result of base pairing rules, thymine can only pair with adenine through the formation of two hydrogen bonds seen in DNA, as shown below: CC By 4.0

question.text: Which of the following organic molecule monomer-polymer pairs is incorrectly matched?

explanation.concept_text: Biological polymers are large molecules comprised of many smaller, similar molecules ( monomers ) that are linked together in a chain-like fashion. Proteins, carbohydrates (polysaccharides), nucleic acids, and lipids are the four major classes of biological macromolecules or polymers. Lipids do not have their own distinct monomer and are instead characterized by generally having hydrocarbon chains and largely non-polar properties. Heme is a porphyrin molecule that is a necessary component of hemoglobin. Porphyrins are not lipids.

question.text: Which of the following is considered the smallest unit of matter?

explanation.concept_text: Matter is anything that takes up space, and has mass. Matter can be living or non-living, so while the cell is the smallest unit of life, atoms are much smaller than cells and are considered the smallest unit of matter. Each atom is made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons.

question.text: Which of the following causes chemical bonds to form?

explanation.concept_text: Chemical bonds are the result of electrons being shared between atoms. Groups of 2+ atoms held together by chemical bonds are called molecules .

question.text: Which of the following properties directly determines what type of chemical bond is formed?

explanation.concept_text: Electronegativity is the ability of an atom to attract electrons. Highly electronegative atoms hold their electrons close to their nucleus and strongly attract the electrons of other atoms. Atoms with lower electronegativity hold their electrons further away and are less attracted to the electrons of other atoms. Since chemical bonds are the result of electrons being shared between atoms, the difference in electronegativity between the two atoms determines what type of chemical bond forms (ionic, covalent, etc.).

question.text: All of the following molecules can participate in hydrogen bonding EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: A molecule that has a nitrogen atom bound to a hydrogen atom

options.label: B.
options.text: A molecule that has an oxygen atom bound to a hydrogen atom

options.label: C.
options.text: A molecule that has a sulfur atom bound to a hydrogen atom

options.label: D.
options.text: A molecule that has a fluorine atom bound to a hydrogen atom

options.label: E.
options.text: All of the above molecules could participate in hydrogen bonding

correct_answer_text: A molecule that has a sulfur atom bound to a hydrogen atom

explanation.concept_text: Hydrogen bonds are weak bonds that can form between molecules having a hydrogen atom covalently attached to a Fluorine, Oxygen, or Nitrogen (F, O, N) atom. Since F, O, and N atoms are highly electronegative , they can become attracted to a negative charge on another molecule that has an F, O, or N. Hydrogen bonds are particular important in the structures of water and DNA.

question.text: Which of the following best describes Van der Waals interactions?

options.label: A.
options.text: Strong dipoles that form between two molecules that are close together

options.label: B.
options.text: The force that holds the two strands of DNA together in a double helix

options.label: C.
options.text: Interactions that only occur between polar molecules

options.label: D.
options.text: Weak, transient attractions that become stronger the larger a molecule is

options.label: E.
options.text: Permanent dipole-dipole interactions that occur between small molecules

correct_answer_text: Weak, transient attractions that become stronger the larger a molecule is

explanation.concept_text: Rather than being true chemical bonds, Van der Waals interactions are weak attractions due to differing distributions of electrons. These are temporary interactions that change as electrons randomly move around an atom’s nucleus. Larger atoms and molecules can have stronger Van der Waals interactions because these transient electrostatic attractions become stronger when more electrons are present.

question.text: Which of the following is the phase diagram of water?

explanation.concept_text: Water’s phase diagram is unique because the slope of the line between the liquid and solid form is negative, rather than positive like most other substances. This means that if you start with solid water (ice) and increase the pressure, it will change into liquid water. This is because in liquid water, the water molecules are closer together than they are in ice (ice is less dense than water). The structured hydrogen bonds in ice prevent the molecules from getting as close together, leading to the decreased density. In most other substances, if you increase the pressure on a liquid, it will transition to the solid phase. This translates to a positive slope between the liquid and solid forms.

question.text: Minerals can be described as ________.

options.label: A.
options.text: Inorganic ions found intracellularly and extracellularly

options.label: D.
options.text: Organic molecules that are only found in the Earth

options.label: E.
options.text: Organic or inorganic molecules that are fat soluble

correct_answer_text: Inorganic ions found intracellularly and extracellularly

explanation.concept_text: Minerals are inorganic ions (like Ca 2+ or K + ) that the human body needs to function. They can be found both intracellularly and extracellularly.

question.text: All of the following are functions of minerals EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: B.
options.text: Electrochemical gradients of muscle and nerve function

options.label: D.
options.text: Component of hemoglobin in red blood cells

explanation.concept_text: Minerals are inorganic ions (like Ca 2+ or K + ) that the human body needs to function. They can be found both intracellularly and extracellularly. Minerals have a wide variety of functions including playing a critical role in bone development, establishing electrochemical gradients for muscle and nerve function, serving as a source of ions for biological functions, and being a component of hemoglobin in red blood cells. However, they do not play a direct critical role in energy production.

question.text: Vitamins are organic molecules that are needed for human body function. Which of the following may occur due to vitamin overconsumption?

options.label: A.
options.text: Overconsumed fat-soluble vitamins can be excreted in urine

options.label: B.
options.text: Overconsumed water-soluble vitamins can build up in the blood, causing health issues

options.label: C.
options.text: Any type of overconsumed vitamin will likely cause health issues

options.label: D.
options.text: Overconsumed fat-soluble vitamins can deposit in body fat, causing health issues

options.label: E.
options.text: Any type of vitamin overconsumption can be excreted in urine

correct_answer_text: Overconsumed fat-soluble vitamins can deposit in body fat, causing health issues

explanation.concept_text: Vitamins can be water-soluble, or fat-soluble. Water-soluble vitamins can be excreted in urine when they are consumed in excess, however, fat- soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, and K) cannot be excreted in the urine. Fat-soluble vitamins can instead deposit in body fat, and overconsumption can lead to toxic levels in the body. Overconsumption of water-soluble vitamins is not considered dangerous or harmful to health, while overconsumption of fat-soluble vitamins is.

question.text: All of the following are true regarding vitamins EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: B vitamins often function as coenzymes in metabolic processes

options.label: B.
options.text: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy

options.label: C.
options.text: Vitamin A is important for vision and maintaining the epithelium of the skin

options.label: E.
options.text: Vitamin K is synthesized when UV light hits the skin

correct_answer_text: Vitamin K is synthesized when UV light hits the skin

explanation.concept_text: Vitamins are organic molecules that the human body needs to function. Important vitamins to know for the test include:

question.text: All of the following are fat-soluble vitamins EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Vitamins can be water-soluble, or fat-soluble. Water-soluble vitamins can be excreted in urine when they are consumed in excess, however, fat- soluble vitamins cannot be excreted in the urine and can be hazardous to health if overconsumed. The four fat-soluble vitamins are Vitamins A, D, E, and K ( ADEK ).

question.text: Which of the following are used to link nucleotides on the same strand to each other?

explanation.concept_text: Nucleotides are linked together via covalent phosphodiester bonds between the 5’ phosphate group of one nucleotide and the 3’ OH group of the next, forming nucleic acids. Phosphodiester bonds are formed through dehydration synthesis (loss of a water molecule). Hydrogen bonds are also present in some nucleic acids, but they do not link nucleotides on the same strand together. Instead, hydrogen bonds are used to hold together nucleotides on two opposing strands of DNA, forming a double helix.

question.text: Which of the following pairs of polysaccharides are unbranched (linear)?

explanation.concept_text: Polysaccharides are the polymer form of carbohydrates. They consist of repeating monosaccharide units that are linked by covalent glycosidic bonds . Starch, glycogen, cellulose, and chitin are all polymers of repeating glucose monomers. However, starch and glycogen both have branched structures and alpha glycosidic linkages, while cellulose and chitin are both linear (unbranched) with beta glycosidic linkages.

question.text: Which polysaccharide is known to contain nitrogen groups in its structure?

explanation.concept_text: Chitin , a linear glucose polysaccharide, contains nitrogen groups in its structure. Chitin’s main function is to provide structural support in fungal cell walls and insect exoskeletons.

question.text: Beta glycosidic linkages _____.

options.label: A.
options.text: Form with the addition of a water molecule

options.label: B.
options.text: Require special gut bacteria in order to be digested

options.label: C.
options.text: Are found in polysaccharides such as glycogen

options.label: E.
options.text: Can only form between glucose molecules

correct_answer_text: Require special gut bacteria in order to be digested

explanation.concept_text: Humans are readily able to digest the alpha glycosidic linkages found in polysaccharides such as starch and glycogen. However, we cannot digest the beta glycosidic linkages found in polysaccharides like cellulose and chitin. Human digestive systems lack the enzymes needed to break beta glycosidic linkages, but some animals (such as cows) have special bacteria in their guts that produce the necessary enzymes for digestion.

question.text: Hydrolysis can be used to break all of the following molecules into smaller constituents EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Hydrolysis (the addition of a water molecule) is the reverse process of dehydration synthesis (the loss of a water molecule). All of the biological macromolecules (proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids) have monomer units that are linked together via dehydration synthesis, and can thus be broken apart into their monomers via hydrolysis. Although amino acids undergo dehydration synthesis to link to each other and form proteins, a single amino acid cannot be broken down into smaller constituents via hydrolysis alone.

question.text: Glycerol’s structure can be described as _____.

options.label: A.
options.text: A three-carbon chain with an –OH group attached to each carbon atom

options.label: B.
options.text: A long carbon chain ending in a carboxylic acid group

options.label: C.
options.text: Four fused hydrocarbon rings with a polar group on one end

options.label: D.
options.text: A six-carbon chain including two double bonds

options.label: E.
options.text: A three-carbon chain with a phosphate group and two fatty acids

correct_answer_text: A three-carbon chain with an –OH group attached to each carbon atom

explanation.concept_text: Glycerol is a three-carbon molecule that has an –OH group attached to each carbon. Glycerol is commonly found as the backbone of lipid structures such as phospholipids and fatty acids.

question.text: All of the following can be associated with steroids EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Steroids are a type of lipid that have a structure composed of four fused rings. Steroids include molecules such as hormones (signaling molecules), cholesterol, and vitamin D. Porphyrins are a separate type of biological molecule that are comprised of four joined pyrrole rings (which are not the same as the rings found in steroid molecules) with a metal ion in the center, as show below. Porphyrins are not steroids, nor are they considered lipid molecules.

question.text: Which of the following molecules are porphyrins?

explanation.concept_text: Porphyrins are a type of biological molecule that are comprised of four joined pyrrole rings with a metal ion in the center, as show below. Porphyrins are not lipids. Hemoglobin and chlorophyll share a similar structure, and are common examples of porphyrins.

question.text: Which of the following often have a metal ion complexed within their structure?

explanation.concept_text: Porphyrins are a type of biological molecule that are comprised of four joined pyrrole rings with a metal ion in the center, as show below. Common porphyrin molecules include hemoglobin and chlorophyll. Porphyrins are not lipids.

question.text: Which level of protein structure is directly determined by the nucleotide sequence of mRNA?

explanation.concept_text: Protein structure and organization is split into four levels: primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary. Primary protein structure is the linear sequence of amino acids that is connected by peptide bonds. The order of amino acids in a protein is directly determined by the sequence of nucleotides in the mRNA strand that codes for that particular protein. This is because when proteins are created during the process of translation (See Ch 9 Molecular Genetics), an mRNA strand is translated into a corresponding sequence of amino acids.

question.text: While trying to identify a particular substance, a scientist observes the presence of sulfur. This substance is likely a ______.

explanation.concept_text: Proteins are the only macromolecule that exhibit disulfide bonds and sulfur atoms in general. Thus, the presence of sulfur often suggests the presence of proteins. Disulfide bonds are covalent interactions between two cysteine amino acids that make up part of a protein’s tertiary structure.

question.text: All of the following are conditions that may cause protein denaturation EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Protein denaturation is when a protein completely loses its 3D structure due to external factors and reverts to its linear, primary structure .  Protein denaturation can be caused by extreme heat, exposure to strong acids or bases, certain chemicals, salt concentration changes, UV light, and more. Denatured proteins are non-functional . Cytosol is present inside of all cells, where proteins are often found. Exposure to cytosol does not usually cause protein denaturation.

question.text: DNA’s structure and function can be associated with all of the following EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Peptide bonds are found in proteins to covalently link amino acids together. DNA is a nucleic acid, whose main role is to store, transmit, and express the genetic information of cells. DNA is comprised of nucleotides that are linked via phosphodiester bonds that can base pair to opposite DNA strands via hydrogen bonds.

question.text: Which of the following DNA strands would have the highest melting point?

explanation.concept_text: The melting temperature of a DNA strand refers to the temperature required to break the hydrogen bonding base pairs and separate the two strands. DNA strands with a higher concentration of Cytosine and Guanine nucleotides have higher melting points, because C and G are held together with 3 hydrogen bonds, while Adenine and Thymine are only held together with 2 hydrogen bonds. Although this question’s answer choices only provide the sequence for one of the DNA strands, only one of the strands is necessary to determine which choice would have the most G-C bonds, and thus the highest melting point.

question.text: Which of the following is a difference between DNA and RNA?

options.label: A.
options.text: DNA’s ribose sugar has an extra hydrogen atom on C2

options.label: B.
options.text: RNA’s ribose sugar has an extra –OH group on C2

options.label: C.
options.text: DNA’s deoxyribose sugar has an extra –OH group on C3

options.label: D.
options.text: RNA’s deoxyribose sugar has an extra hydrogen atom on C2

options.label: E.
options.text: DNA is single stranded while RNA is usually double stranded

correct_answer_text: RNA’s ribose sugar has an extra –OH group on C2

explanation.concept_text: One of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA)’ s main structural differences is that DNA is composed of a deoxyribose sugar, while RNA has a ribose sugar. Deoxyribose and ribose are both 5-carbon sugar molecules, except ribose (RNA) has an –OH group on C2, while deoxyribose (DNA) has an –H atom on C2.

question.text: If a sample of DNA has 20% guanine, then what percentage of thymine does it have?

explanation.concept_text: Chargaff’s Rule states that the number of purines is always equal to the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded nucleic acid ( A+G = T+C ). Since in DNA, the nucleotide bases are always paired as listed below, the following nucleotide bases are also always found in equal amounts Using this rule, if the DNA is 20% guanine, then it must also be 20% cytosine. This leaves 60% for adenine and thymine, so the strand must be 30% Adenine and 30% Thymine.

question.text: Phosphodiester bonds link nucleotides together by connecting the __________.

options.label: A.
options.text: Phosphate group of one nucleotide to the five carbon sugar of another

options.label: B.
options.text: Individual strands of nucleic acid to produce a double-stranded molecule

options.label: C.
options.text: Phosphate group of one nucleotide to the phosphate group of another

options.label: D.
options.text: Five carbon sugar of one nucleotide to the sugar of another

options.label: E.
options.text: -OH group of one nucleotide to the -OH group of another

correct_answer_text: Phosphate group of one nucleotide to the five carbon sugar of another

explanation.concept_text: Phosphodiester bonds are the covalent bonds that link nucleotide monomers to create nucleic acid polymers. Individual nucleotides have three components: a 5-carbon sugar, a nitrogenous base, and a phosphate group. In the 5-carbon sugar, the 3’ carbon has an –OH group while the 5’ carbon is attached to the phosphate group. Phosphodiester bonds link the 5’ phosphate group of one nucleotide, and the 3’ -OH group of the next. The formation of this bond also effectively links the phosphate group of the first nucleotide to the sugar of the next one, as shown below:

question.text: Phosphodiester bonds link nucleotides together by connecting the __________.

options.label: A.
options.text: Phosphate group of one nucleotide to the five carbon sugar of another

options.label: B.
options.text: Individual strands of nucleic acid to produce a double-stranded molecule

options.label: C.
options.text: Phosphate group of one nucleotide to the phosphate group of another

options.label: D.
options.text: Five carbon sugar of one nucleotide to the sugar of another

options.label: E.
options.text: -OH group of one nucleotide to the -OH group of another

correct_answer_text: Phosphate group of one nucleotide to the five carbon sugar of another

explanation.concept_text: Phosphodiester bonds are the covalent bonds that link nucleotide monomers to create nucleic acid polymers. Individual nucleotides have three components: a 5-carbon sugar, a nitrogenous base, and a phosphate group. In the 5-carbon sugar, the 3’ carbon has an –OH group while the 5’ carbon is attached to the phosphate group. Phosphodiester bonds link the 5’ phosphate group of one nucleotide, and the 3’ -OH group of the next. The formation of this bond also effectively links the phosphate group of the first nucleotide to the sugar of the next one, as shown below:
